meta.interest: [2025-08-05] We are tracking AI labor solutions for logistics and trucking recruitment but do not find current approaches compelling. We prefer logistics infrastructure plays with broader applicability beyond driver churn reduction.

[2025-08-05] Really excited about robotics, especially in industrial settings where safety is critical
.

[2025-08-05] While we see potential in the home health or industrial robotics space, we are concerned about go-to-market challenges, vertical-specific sales processes, and the lack of commercially ready traction. Armstrong's dishwasher robot highlighted for us the difficulty of scaling robotics technology due to training complexity, despite its long-term potential.
.

[2025-08-05] We're excited about robotics and sensor-native foundation models as a wedge into the physical world. Archetype, building a foundation model for the physical world via multimodal sensor data, stood out for its enterprise traction and generalizable safety/compliance applications. We are particularly interested in platforms that abstract physical sensor data into programmable intelligence, as a path to robotics software scale. However, we are sensitive to round dynamics and will push for structured entry (e.g., discount to A or interim rounds).
.

[2025-08-05] We continue to prioritize frontier robotics with real unit economic leverage and software advantage. Veer Robotics (facade-cleaning robots) fits squarely in our robotics thesis: replacing high-risk manual labor with vertically-integrated automation that also captures unique inspection data. We're sensitive to capital efficiency, leasing models, and software data upsell opportunities. Preference for teams transitioning from semi-autonomous to fully autonomous over time.
.

[2025-08-05] We continue to track vertical robotics that replace dangerous and repetitive manual labor, especially where recurring leasing models and inspection data upsells can drive software margins. Hardware reliability, unit economics (multi-robot per operator), and defensibility beyond suction/IP remain key diligence points. Sensitive to lack of frontier VC traction.

[2025-07-29] We are actively tracking foundational infrastructure for robotics — from simulation platforms to real-time operating systems — as critical enablers of the next wave of physical AI. Startups like Foxglove and Xronos that abstract complexity in robot development and deployment align well with our belief in verticalized automation with software leverage..
meta.thesis: Physical AI: Robotic Applications and Foundational Infra

meta.interest:
[2025-10-13] We are tracking AI procurement and sourcing automation for industrial commodities. Systems negotiating across global supplier bases (Alibaba, India, China) with price-visibility analytics can reduce cost variance for high-volume buyers (> $100M spend). Filters: proven cost-reduction impact (> 5%), automated quote normalization across regions, and escrow or financing mechanisms embedded in flow. Risks: thin transaction margins, complex logistics / compliance layers, and exposure to commodity-price cycles.

[2025-09-02] We are tracking digital metal service centers modernizing U.S. re-industrialization. Next-day cut metals with software-driven quoting and inventory are compelling, but margins hinge on mill relationships and two-sided marketplace liquidity. Filters: instant quoting adoption, supply contracts with mills, and SKU-level telemetry feeding predictive procurement.
...

[2025-09-29] We are interested in AI-native procurement and preconstruction platforms. Neuron Fracture leverages proprietary historical data from Cordial and has already won seven enterprise clients with short sales cycles. Filters: data moats built from proprietary bid/pricing histories, ability to replace Excel-based workflows, strong early commercial traction. Risks: high entry valuation expectations ($25M pre-seed, raising $10M), competitive noise in preconstruction tech, uncertainty around acquirer appetite (EPCs vs Autodesk/Procore).

[2025-09-22] We are tracking vertical commerce/OS plays for aesthetics and similar fragmented industries. Procurement marketplaces alone risk margin compression; stronger wedge is back-office OS (scheduling, payments, purchasing) with group-buying as feature. Filters: long-tail fragmentation, embedded financial leverage..

[2025-08-26] We are interested in verticalized AI platforms for payer procurement and vendor management; the problem is real (multi-year approval cycles, vendor fatigue), but defensibility against large incumbents like Microsoft is questionable. Filters: mid-sized plan adoption, regulatory trust, path beyond pilots.
.

meta.interest:
[2025-08-28] We remain cautious on sales tax automation platforms at later-stage valuations. While regulatory tailwinds create urgency, the market is likely to consolidate into one or two winners. We will not pursue late-stage entries unless we have a differentiated wedge or asymmetric entry point.

[2025-08-07] We discussed companies like Vadera Labs and others in AI-driven appraisals for niche markets (e.g., collectibles, industrial equipment). These markets are interesting to us, but we see challenges in validation, scalability, and market size that limit their appeal.
.

[2025-08-05] We are excited about AI legal tech platforms focused on negotiation and deal optimization for operators, not just lawyers. We prefer tools that replace legal process fees with revenue-generating AI services (e.g., automated term sheet negotiation, contract optimization for GCs and CROs).
.

[2025-07-30] We are interested in legal tech, but skeptical of generic tooling plays. We prefer verticalized legal platforms focused on specific high-volume categories (e.g., small claims, insurance defense) where AI replaces human workflow. Selling to GCs or law firms directly remains difficult unless there's a deeply embedded GTM edge or AI-native operational model. We are more excited about full-stack AI law firms than horizontal legal SaaS.
.

[2025-07-29] We’re excited about AI-native commerce infrastructure — from agentic shopping assistants to intelligent procurement and recommence platforms. Companies like Fermat and Coupa exemplify our interest in replacing fragmented stacks with adaptive systems that personalize experiences, optimize supply chains, and support circular consumption models..
meta.caution: Has to be a strong wedge against legacy players and a clear vertical focus.

meta.interest: Interested in infrastructure that enables new forms of transaction logic from dynamic pricing to alternative payments and payment acceptance in underserved markets. Value high attach-rate, API-first platforms with network effects.. [2025-07-30] Export-focused fintech (e.g., Shield) is interesting if paired with AI and infrastructure plays. We are seeing underserved export markets emerge as fintech infrastructure opportunities, especially when compliance and onboarding are automated using AI. We're looking for fintech infra companies that can build end-to-end export platforms and monetize risk, data, or workflow layers. Margins, take rates, and use-case expansion (e.g., cards, treasury) matter.
meta.caution: Pure payment orchestration or Stripe clones with no clear wedge or vertical focus are a pass. Low take-rate, commoditized rails are also unattractive unless paired with monetizable adjacencies.

meta.interest: We like companies embedding lending, insurance, or other financial products directly into commerce platforms, especially where timing, underwriting, or product design is tailored to the merchant or transaction type.
meta.caution: Skeptical of embedded finance platforms that rely solely on partner APIs and don’t own the underwriting, risk, or distribution advantage.

meta.interest: Looking for fraud prevention platforms that combine real-time decisioning with machine learning models trained on rich, proprietary datasets, especially those embedded into high-volume transaction flows.
meta.caution: We are cautious around standalone tools with limited data network effects or weak integration into the broader commerce stack.

meta.interest: We're selectively interested in marketing infrastructure that drives measurable revenue lift for commerce businesses, especially through automation, personalization, or new distribution channels. Preference for infra-like products with defensible positioning, not workflow-heavy point solutions.
meta.caution: We are cautious around horizontal marketing tools with low switching costs or products that resemble agencies or consulting services. Marketing automation is a crowded space, differentiation and performance attribution must be clear.

meta.interest: [2025-09-22] We are tracking embedded AI-driven marketing automation for SMB SaaS platforms. Filters: ability to sell through vertical SaaS distributors (e.g. Mindbody, Peak), automate multi-channel campaigns (email, text, referral), and monetize as embedded upsell. Attractive wedge if distribution replaces SMB acquisition.

[2025-08-28] We are skeptical of wallet-based marketing channels unless distribution and engagement economics are proven at scale. While push-enabled offers in native Apple/Google/Samsung wallets can create a new owned channel for enterprises, sub-$1M ARR and heavy reliance on partnerships (e.g., Blackhawk Network) limit defensibility. Filters: ability to own enterprise relationships, sustained opt-in engagement, and category leadership before platform owners close the channel.
Open to hearing about innovation here, but it has to be strong and especially important to have a strong founding team.

meta.description: Covers technology that transforms how physical industries operate—spanning infrastructure, heavy assets, energy-intensive processes, and complex operational environments.
Platforms and technologies that improve production efficiency, flexibility, or traceability across physical goods manufacturing, including automation, robotics, and digital twins.

meta.interest:
[2025-09-17] We are tracking digital metal service centers modernizing U.S. re-industrialization. Next-day cut metals with software-driven quoting and inventory are compelling, but margins hinge on mill relationships and two-sided marketplace liquidity. Filters: instant quoting adoption, supply contracts with mills, and SKU-level telemetry feeding predictive procurement.
.

meta.description: Vertical software platforms serving industrial operators with tools for operations, maintenance, asset tracking, compliance, or ERP replacement in industrial environments.
Encompasses tech that streamlines construction planning, execution, labor coordination, compliance, and materials management, with emphasis on software-enabled workflows and industrial automation.
One of Montage's main focus areas.

meta.interest:
[2025-10-13] We are tracking AI-enabled monitoring platforms for nursing homes and long-term care. Computer vision, voice, and sensor systems that detect falls, breathing irregularities, or neurological issues can improve per-bed economics for operators. Filters: concentration of major operators (10–15 control large swaths), ability to prove ROI on reduced care costs, and potential domino adoption once a design partner converts. Risks: deeply relationship-driven industry, outsider tech teams may struggle to penetrate, and fragmented mid-tail market may limit scalability.

[2025-10-06] We are tracking clinician-workflow-integrated AI monitoring for high-toxicity treatments. AI systems that passively capture patient health signals between oncology visits can reduce ER incidents and strengthen drug-margin economics for in-house pharmacies. Filters: seamless EMR overlay integration, validated improvement in intervention timing, and clear reimbursement pathways for care-team usage. Risks: workflow inertia within provider networks, data-privacy hurdles, and long clinical validation cycles delaying scale..

meta.interest:
[2025-08-07] We are interested in healthcare data monetization, but we are concerned about regulatory challenges, long sales cycles, and lack of differentiation in existing solutions like Truveta. We prefer AI-focused solutions rather than pure bioinformatics or diagnostics due to monetization and scalability challenges.

[2025-08-05] NOT interested in pure biotech companies (e.g. biopharma, biotech, etc.) - prefer more Techbio 
.

[2025-08-05] If it's healthcare related, we are interested in techbio and more tech forward companies, not biotech and not pharma and not medical devices and hardware. 
.

[2025-08-05] We are interested in techbio platforms that treat mRNA as an engineering substrate, not a modality. Closed-loop design systems that optimize for expression durability and tissue targeting unlock large therapeutic white spaces. Key filters: proprietary data generation, software leverage, and co-founder teams blending deep science with ML engineering.
.

[2025-08-05] We are interested in platforms that can high-throughput map antibody-protein interactions for autoimmunity, but remain cautious of biotech plays that lack clear software leverage. Informatics layers that accelerate discovery pipelines without requiring new biology are attractive, but GTM clarity and tech differentiation are non-negotiable filters.
.
meta.description: TechBio companies apply advanced computational methods — including machine learning, simulation, and high-throughput data generation — to accelerate discovery, design, and development in life sciences. Unlike traditional biotech, which typically carries binary FDA risk and long development cycles, TechBio firms often monetize earlier through platform licensing, SaaS-like models, or data/insight sales. Core themes include AI-driven drug discovery, synthetic biology design platforms, lab automation, and molecular simulation infrastructure.

meta.interest:
[2025-08-07] NOT interested in pure biotech companies (e.g. biopharma, biotech, etc.) - prefer more Techbio 
. [2025-08-07] If it's healthcare related, we are interested in techbio and more tech forward companies, not biotech and not pharma and not medical devices and hardware. 


[2025-10-13] We are tracking biopharma data platforms generating mechanism-driven biological datasets. Companies rebuilding molecular models from mechanistic or phenotypic pathways can serve as AI data infrastructure for next-generation drug discovery. Filters: proprietary mechanistic datasets, early pharma design-partner traction, and clear monetization via data licensing or SaaS. Risks: unclear productization beyond data services, high experimental cost to maintain freshness, and overlap with CRO revenue models.

[2025-10-06] We are interested in AI-first drug discovery platforms that optimize for patient outcomes rather than target binding. Generative models that screen billions of compounds in silico can compress discovery timelines from years to weeks, particularly valuable in oncology, rare diseases, and immunology where datasets are small. Filters: patient-relevant hits, ability to bypass target-structure constraints, and integration with proprietary or exclusive datasets. Risks: defensibility depends on data ownership, validation beyond initial indications, and ability to translate scientific wins into commercial partnerships..

[2025-08-28] not interested in pure biotech companies (e.g. biopharma, biotech, etc.) - prefer more Techbio 
.

[2025-08-28] If it's healthcare related, we are interested in techbio and more tech forward companies, not biotech and not pharma and not medical devices and hardware. 
.

[2025-08-28] We are not investing in biotech plays without a techbio wedge. We passed on companies like Neosplice due to lack of commercial clarity, academic founder posture, and regulatory/scientific risk. Even in cases where there is scientific promise, we look for compelling software leverage, differentiated datasets, and go-to-market plans that avoid single-asset development traps.
.

[2025-08-28] We are interested in techbio platforms that treat mRNA as an engineering substrate, not a modality. Closed-loop design systems that optimize for expression durability and tissue targeting unlock large therapeutic white spaces. Key filters: proprietary data generation, software leverage, and co-founder teams blending deep science with ML engineering.
.

[2025-08-28] We are interested in platforms that can high-throughput map antibody-protein interactions for autoimmunity, but remain cautious of biotech plays that lack clear software leverage. Informatics layers that accelerate discovery pipelines without requiring new biology are attractive, but GTM clarity and tech differentiation are non-negotiable filters.
.

[2025-08-28] We are interested in AI-native lab platforms targeting synthesis bottlenecks in drug discovery. Natural-language-to-experiment design connected to robotic execution could compress timelines by orders of magnitude. Timing is favorable as LLMs now reason over chemistry reliably. Filters: proprietary integration into lab workflows, quality of pharma partnerships, and pace of execution. Defensibility must extend beyond access to LLMs.

[2025-08-19] We are interested in AI-driven lab platforms that close the loop between image-based phenotyping, multi-omics readouts, and hypothesis generation to accelerate oncology drug discovery. The opportunity lies in combining high-throughput experimental feedback with predictive models to identify novel mechanisms in a fraction of traditional timelines. Filters: strength of founding team across ML and wet lab execution, ability to generate proprietary datasets, and clear differentiation from existing image-omics players.
....

[2025-09-17] We are interested in AI pathology platforms that go beyond diagnostics to stratify patients and accelerate clinical trials (e.g., bone marrow disease imaging). Filters: pharma partnerships, regulatory clarity, mechanistic depth.
.

meta.interest:
[2025-09-17] We are tracking AI-first genomic design platforms. COVID validated mRNA delivery; the unlock is now sequence optimization and proprietary synthetic data generation. Filters: full wet-lab loop (not just annotations), ability to build a defensible data moat, and technical founders with pharma traction.
.

meta.interest:
[2025-10-13] We are tracking vertically specialized fintech platforms serving professional associations. SMB-oriented financial suites for niche trades (pharmacists, veterinarians, welders) can achieve durable deposits and zero-loss lending economics. Filters: exclusive association partnerships, AR/AP automation within workflow, and ≥10K active small-business accounts. Risks: slow multi-association scaling, margin pressure from regional banks, and potential feature overlap with Ramp/Brex if they move down-market.

[2025-09-29] We are tracking fintech infrastructure that embeds equipment or asset financing at the point of sale. Fragmented workflows create opportunities for agentic financing platforms that streamline underwriting and distribution. Filters: distribution secured via OEMs or vertical SaaS, defensibility beyond simple capital provision, and ability to scale efficiently in fragmented verticals. Risks: timing of adoption, capital intensity, and risk of adverse selection if distribution is not locked in early..

[2025-07-29] We are excited about agentic infrastructure, but cautious around horizontal B2B SaaS without clear fintech or commerce applications.: While platforms like Roya (commercial agent orchestration) and RTXEN (agentic FinOps OS) show promise, our core value-add is stronger when there is a verticalized GTM, such as fintech or commerce. We prefer use cases where orchestration layers have clear commercial outputs or data feedback loops, not generic dashboards or BI tools. We're also mindful of intense early competition and commoditization in agent infra...

meta.interest: [2025-07-30] Export-focused fintech (e.g., Shield) is interesting if paired with AI and infrastructure plays. We are seeing underserved export markets emerge as fintech infrastructure opportunities, especially when compliance and onboarding are automated using AI. We're looking for fintech infra companies that can build end-to-end export platforms and monetize risk, data, or workflow layers. Margins, take rates, and use-case expansion (e.g., cards, treasury) matter.

meta.interest:
[2025-10-13] We are interested in payments routing and enrichment infrastructure. By enriching transactions with additional metadata (MCC, SKU-level, tax fields, card-present flags), platforms can optimize interchange rates and deliver direct merchant savings. Filters: ability to achieve certification advantages (e.g., CEDP), enterprise adoption at scale, and recurring revenue tied to volume. Risks: nuanced sales motions may slow adoption, incumbents can undercut pricing, and competitive dynamics may mirror fraud/chargeback consolidation..

[2025-10-13] Agentic finance (wallets, spend control, transaction logic) is a key adjacency — payments will be the first real-world domain for autonomous agents.

[2025-09-29] We are tracking AI-native billing and usage-based payments infrastructure. Lark Payments (ex-Stripe engineers) and Lava Payments both address the gap in token-based and credit-expiring billing that Stripe cannot handle natively. Filters: AI-native usage models, developer-first adoption, stablecoin integration. Risks: crowded landscape (Paid, Metronome, wrappers on Stripe), early go-to-market strategies still developing, and need for clearer product vision to scale beyond initial developer traction.We are interested in next-generation billing and payments infrastructure for AI-native and usage-based business models. Paid.ai, backed by EQT and Sequoia, is the most credible team in the space (Manny Medina, ex-Outreach). Lava and Lark validate strong developer pain but lack the product depth and founder profile to win a winner-take-all market. Filters: AI-driven usage billing, stablecoin integration, agentic payment flows. Risks: crowded space (Paid, Metronome, Autumn, wrappers on Stripe), and weaker founders may get acquired acqui-hire style rather than scale...

Excited about seamless FX orchestration, especially for SMBs and global SaaS platforms.. [2025-08-11] Export-focused fintech (e.g., Shield) is interesting if paired with AI and infrastructure plays. We are seeing underserved export markets emerge as fintech infrastructure opportunities, especially when compliance and onboarding are automated using AI. We're looking for fintech infra companies that can build end-to-end export platforms and monetize risk, data, or workflow layers. Margins, take rates, and use-case expansion (e.g., cards, treasury) matter.
. [2025-08-11] We are interested in B2B cross-border payments platforms combining regulated banking infrastructure with stablecoin settlement rails. Integration into local real-time payment systems (e.g., Brazil’s PICS) plus multi-currency named accounts and FX liquidity APIs creates high switching costs for enterprise customers. Key filters: regulatory moat, stablecoin + fiat settlement in one platform, and enterprise adoption in emerging markets. We are sensitive to heavy early revenue concentration.
meta.caution: Hard to compete on cost/FX spread unless paired with workflow or data moat.
meta.description: B2B and B2C platforms handling FX, remittances, treasury routing, and compliance in cross-border payments.

meta.interest:
[2025-08-05] We are interested in infrastructure for stablecoin-based treasury management and corporate payments, particularly for European and global use cases. We are mindful of US regulatory hurdles for yield-generating stablecoin products.
.

[2025-08-05] Stablecoin infrastructure is a core emerging theme. We believe the market is bifurcating into (1) orchestration platforms for global, programmable money movement (e.g., DO, Wallapay) and (2) enterprise-grade stablecoin treasury management for corporates (e.g., Crypto, Velocity). We are open to placing multiple bets in both categories. We look for strong global licensing footprints, enterprise traction, and Stripe-level developer experiences. Founders with Revolut/Worldpay-style DNA are a plus. Regulatory defensibility and speed of GTM execution will determine winners.

[2025-07-30] We are actively tracking stablecoin-based FX and cross-border payment orchestration platforms like DO and Crypto/Fipto. We're particularly interested in infrastructure that abstracts on-chain complexity while unlocking speed and cost advantages over traditional rails..
meta.caution: We are cautious of consumer-facing crypto payment apps without regulatory clarity, enterprise traction, or clear advantages over traditional options.
meta.thesis: Stablecoins: Emerging Global Payment Rail and Financial Platform
meta.description: Covers payment infrastructure using stablecoins, on-chain settlement networks, cross-border FX via crypto rails, and programmable finance layers.

meta.interest: Interested when linked to commerce infrastructure or when driving measurable conversion lift.
meta.caution: We are cautious of standalone checkout optimization tools without network effects or vertical traction.
meta.thesis: Stablecoins: Emerging Global Payment Rail and Financial Platform
meta.description: Front-end checkout experiences, fraud detection at checkout, embedded financing at point-of-sale, one-click and recurring billing systems.
Encompasses core banking tech, APIs, ledger infra, KYC/AML infra, compliance tooling.

meta.thesis: The Great Wealth Shift: Transforming Financial Legacies

meta.description: Deep Tech refers to startups and technologies rooted in significant scientific or engineering innovations that typically require long development cycles, specialized knowledge, and technical defensibility. These companies often emerge from advances in fields such as materials science, robotics, quantum computing, aerospace, energy systems, semiconductors, photonics, and synthetic biology. Unlike applications of AI, which may focus on data and software-driven workflows, Deep Tech innovations tend to rely on breakthroughs in physical systems, hardware, or fundamental science.
meta.interest: We are interested in companies that can apply novel deep tech solutions to real world problems in a scalable and profitable way. The founder would have to be exceptional and it would have to be in a vertical where we could add value.

meta.description: Covers consulting firms, professional services, and other service providers that are service businesses, not tech companies. Includes growth advising, strategy consulting, working one-on-one with companies.
meta.interest: Not in scope unless there's a defensible platform or product-led transition.
meta.caution: Service-heavy models lack margin and scale. Watch for descriptions that seem like they're trying to fit into a tech space, but are really service businesses.

meta.interest:
[2025-08-07] We looked at companies like Solurian that are building AI-driven weather forecasting models targeting enterprise clients. While we find the team and technology strong, we have questions about their ability to scale enterprise sales and differentiate from competitors.
.

[2025-08-07] We discussed companies like Vadera Labs and others in AI-driven appraisals for niche markets (e.g., collectibles, industrial equipment). These markets are interesting to us, but we see challenges in validation, scalability, and market size that limit their appeal.
.

[2025-08-07] We are excited about AI legal tech platforms focused on negotiation and deal optimization for operators, not just lawyers. We prefer tools that replace legal process fees with revenue-generating AI services (e.g., automated term sheet negotiation, contract optimization for GCs and CROs).
.

[2025-08-07] We are tracking RPA’s evolution into deterministic AI agents in regulated verticals. We believe flexible, AI-enhanced RPA has near-term adoption advantages in compliance-heavy sectors like healthcare. That said, we are skeptical of RPA startups positioning as horizontal automation tools unless they demonstrate deep vertical traction and defensible infra advantages. Long-term, we expect agents to cannibalize many RPA use cases.
.

[2025-08-07] We continue to de-prioritize consulting-style AI tools and marketplaces. We passed on Thoughtly due to limited AI differentiation and an SMB-focused wedge that lacks breakout potential. We are not looking for low-NRR tooling unless it shows viral bottoms-up adoption or extremely strong sales DNA.
.

[2025-08-07] We are skeptical of standalone accent softening plays as venture-scale businesses. While useful in BPO and call center workflows, the long-term risk is feature-ization by larger AI voice stacks. Platforms that can generalize real-time voice personalization into broader human-AI interfaces may present a more compelling opportunity.
.

[2025-08-07] We remain skeptical of generic compliance tooling startups. Platforms that automate compliance-heavy workflows using AI agents could be interesting, but require deep vertical focus, robust infra defensibility, and clear monetization paths (risk/data layers). We are not investing in broad horizontal compliance SaaS.

meta.interest:
New subcategory created for pipeline companies. Generated on 2025-09-19

[2025-10-13] We are tracking AI construction-design copilots for electrical and mechanical schematics. Platforms that generate compliant schematics in minutes can remove major bottlenecks for contractors and engineering firms bidding on projects. Filters: interoperability with Autodesk / Revit, measured cycle-time reduction (10× faster drafts), and early partnerships with mid-market GCs. Risks: change-management friction in legacy firms, competition from incumbent CAD vendors, and need for continuous code-library updates for safety compliance.

[2025-10-06] We are interested in AI-enabled platforms for preconstruction workflows, particularly RFP triage and risk management. Automating high-cost, high-frequency bid processes creates direct P&L impact for GCs, with potential to expand into contextual project risk management layers. Filters: demonstrable cost savings per RFP, integration with existing workflows, and potential for strategic acquisition. Risks: construction tech adoption remains slow, consensus skepticism persists, and line-item budgets are not well defined..

[2025-10-13] We are cautious on AI compliance and design tools for civil infrastructure projects. Platforms parsing 1,000+ page RFPs and cross-checking design documents promise efficiency in bridge and road projects. Filters: integration into engineering workflows (e.g., Word plugins), accuracy of compliance checks, and ability to reduce costly rework. Risks: timelines in public infrastructure are slow, pain point is less acute than in data centers/industrial projects, and preference may shift toward full-stack AI engineering providers.

[2025-10-06] We are tracking AI applications in patent and IP management. Semantic approaches to prior art search and claims validation could reduce invalidation rates and augment existing legal workflows. Filters: defensibility in preparing and defending claims, ability to complement rather than replace law firms, and hybrid AI + human-in-the-loop models. Risks: consulting-heavy models risk commoditization, scalability is unproven, and pricing pressure may create a race to the bottom.

[2025-10-13] We are tracking AI-driven deepfake and scam detection infrastructure. Startups targeting KYC/ID verification providers with image/video authenticity checks address urgent fraud pain points. Filters: proprietary data generation loops, ability to surpass the 95%+ accuracy threshold to replace human review, and defensibility against large security incumbents. Risks: dataset advantage may be fleeting, enterprises may bundle into broader CISO security stacks, and narrow KYC wedge may not scale into large enterprise budgets.

meta.interest:
[2025-10-13] We are tracking biopharma data platforms generating mechanism-driven biological datasets. Companies rebuilding molecular models from mechanistic or phenotypic pathways can serve as AI data infrastructure for next-generation drug discovery. Filters: proprietary mechanistic datasets, early pharma design-partner traction, and clear monetization via data licensing or SaaS. Risks: unclear productization beyond data services, high experimental cost to maintain freshness, and overlap with CRO revenue models.

[2025-10-06] We are interested in AI-first drug discovery platforms that optimize for patient outcomes rather than target binding. Generative models that screen billions of compounds in silico can compress discovery timelines from years to weeks, particularly valuable in oncology, rare diseases, and immunology where datasets are small. Filters: patient-relevant hits, ability to bypass target-structure constraints, and integration with proprietary or exclusive datasets. Risks: defensibility depends on data ownership, validation beyond initial indications, and ability to translate scientific wins into commercial partnerships..
